newsitem.title: USA: US mortgage-backeds slump in line with Treasuries.
newsitem.headline: US mortgage-backeds slump in line with Treasuries.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities slipped in line with Treasuries on Wednesday, falling as much as 7/32 in current coupons by late afternoon.
Yield spreads between current coupons and Treasuries widened by a whisker after a brief rally that followed the release of a key inflation gauge, said a New York-based trader.
"Yield spreads widened after Treasuries got a little push from consumer prices earlier in the day," he said.
The September Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose an overall 0.3 percent, in line with a Reuters poll.
The core CPI, which excludes food and energy price fluctuations, also rose 0.3 percent in line with average forecasts.

"The trend is that you are going to have some seasonal widening as yearend gets closer," said another trader. "We show (yield spreads) a little bit wider in the past couple of days, but if I had to make a bet, they will tighten short term."
By late afternoon, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent coupons were off 7/32 at 99-06/32, yielding 110 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent pass-throughs were off 6/32 at 99-06/32, and Freddie Mac 30-years were down 7/32 to 99-09/32.
The 10-year note was off 5/32 to yield 6.57 percent. -- Jeff Coelho, 212-859-1562
